item.title: Lisk to Move Developers from Blockchain to Sidechain
item.description:
Lisk to Move Developers from Blockchain to Sidechain

Lisk plans to launch a modular cryptocurrency which it says would satisfy the growing interest to use the blockchain as a decentralized database for different use-cases outside of FinTech May 24.

item.title: ID2020, held at the United Nations, features 'lots and lots of Blockchain'
item.description:
ID2020, held at the United Nations, features 'lots and lots of Blockchain'

During the inaugural ID2020 summit, held at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday, representatives from over 50 technology businesses discussed the world's Identity problems, including representatives from at least half dozen blockchain-centered companies. The purpose of the annual event is to make sure that every human being has access to identity services, even if they have no state-issued identification.

item.title: What Bitcoin Pizza Day Can Teach Us Today
item.description:
What Bitcoin Pizza Day Can Teach Us Today

May 22, 2010 is a day that will forever live as legend in cryptocurrency lore. On that day the first purchase with Bitcoin was made when two pizzas were purchased for 10,000 Bitcoin.

item.title: Where does the money I get from mining bitcoin come from?
item.description:
Where does the money I get from mining bitcoin come from?

Bitcoin noob here. Where does the money I get from mining bitcoin come from? Does bitcoin mining means I "steal" from other people? If yes, should I fear this probability of being robbed while I...

item.title: These cofounders live in separate countries and have never even met - and they're trying to create a new kind of money
item.description:
These cofounders live in separate countries and have never even met - and they're trying to create a new kind of money

Max Kordek is a 24-year-old Bitcoin wiz from Germany. Next week he and his co-founder, 37-year-old Oliver Beddows, will launch their company, Lisk. And Lisk is such an exciting idea that during their 30-day crowdfunding campaign, nearly 4,000 people chipped in a total of $6 million in bitcoin to fund their seed round, Kordek tells Business Insider.

item.title: Money Demystified: How the Blockchain Offers Financial Safety
item.description:
Money Demystified: How the Blockchain Offers Financial Safety

Despite eight years revamping the world of finance, digital currency is still getting a bum rap. Indeed, we can acknowledge the fact that Bitcoin and the blockchain has thus far held a rather short life and faced excessive negativity and competition from traditional financiers, but is that enough to lessen its accomplishments?

item.title: Will The DAO Lead To Legal Trouble For Every Investor?
item.description:
Will The DAO Lead To Legal Trouble For Every Investor?

While nearly every investor is confident the code behind The DAO alone is well worth the investment, that alone should not be the main reason to participate in this crowdsale. Despite the overwhelming success of The DAO so far, a lot of people are still unable to wrap their head around the concept.

item.title: Japanese Government To Monitor Consumer GPS Movements All The Time
item.description:
Japanese Government To Monitor Consumer GPS Movements All The Time

Smartphones have quickly become the internet-connected device of choice for consumers all over the world, due to portability and powerful specifications. But over in Japan, government officials make use of five new smartphones by NTT DoCoMo to secretly track users, including their location.

item.title: Audio Fingerprinting May Become The New Norm To Breach Browsing Privacy
item.description:
Audio Fingerprinting May Become The New Norm To Breach Browsing Privacy

Online tracking of users is become more the norm than the exception these days, and various websites are resorting to audio fingerprinting. The AudioContext API can identify audio signals which may reveal unique information about one's browser and Internet-connected device.

item.title: Japanese Government To Monitor Smartphone GPS Data All The Time
item.description:
Japanese Government To Monitor Smartphone GPS Data All The Time

Smartphones have quickly become the internet-connected device of choice for consumers all over the world, due to portability and powerful specifications. But over in Japan, government officials make use of five new smartphones by NTT DoCoMo to secretly track users, including their location.
